The coding sequence of several mitochondrial mRNAs of the kinetoplastid protozoa is created through the insertion and deletion of specific uridylates. The editing reactions are required to be highly specific in order to ensure that functional open reading frames are created in edited mRNAs and that potentially deleterious modification of normally nonedited sequence does not occur. Selection-amplification and mutagenesis were previously used to identify the optimal sequence requirements for in vitro editing. There is, however, a minority of natural editing sites with suboptimal sequence. Several cis-acting elements, obtained from an in vitro selection, are described here that are able to compensate for a suboptimal editing site. An A + U sequence element within the 5′-untranslated region of cytochrome b mRNA from Leishmania tarentolae is also demonstrated to function as a cis-acting guide RNA and is postulated to compensate for a suboptimal editing site in vivo. Two proteins within an enriched editing extract are UV-cross-linked to two different in vitro selected editing substrates more efficiently than poorly edited RNAs. The results suggest that these proteins contribute to the specificity of the editing reaction. RNA. 2000; 6: 1492-1497Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar), there is a minority of natural editing sites that clearly have a suboptimal sequence. Several different cis-acting elements obtained from the in vitro selection are described here that are able to compensate for a suboptimal editing site. Two proteins of a highly enriched editing extract with apparent molecular weights of 80,000 and 100,000 are UV-cross-linked to two different in vitro selected RNA editing substrates. Cytidines immediately 5′ of the editing site inhibit both editing and the cross-links to these proteins, but both can be compensated by an in vitro selected hairpin loop. The result identifies two proteins that contribute to the specificity of the editing reaction. The in vitro selection also suggested that the cytochrome b mRNA A + U element is functioning as a cis-acting gRNA and this was subsequently confirmed. Editing Extract—A 2-liter L. tarentolae culture (UC strain) was grown to a density of 1.5 × 108 cells/ml at 27 °C in BHI medium (Difco) supplemented with 0.01 mg/ml hemin. The culture was lysed under isotonic conditions using a Stansted Disrupter (Energy Service Co.) at 1200 p.s.i. as previously described (17Connell G. J Byrne E. Simpson L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 4212-4218Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). The mitochondrial fraction was enriched by flotation through a Renografin-60 (diatrizoate meglumine and diatrizoate sodium; Bracco Diagnostics) density gradient (24Braly P. Simpson L. Kretzer F. J. Protozool. 1974; 21: 782-790Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). After three washes in SHE (0.25 m sorbitol, 20 mm Hepes, pH 7.5, 2 mm EDTA), the mitochondrial fraction was resuspended in 3.8 ml of lysis buffer (25 mm Hepes pH 7.5, 10 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 20 mm KCl, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 1 mg/ml Pefabloc, 10 μg/ml leupeptin), and 200 μl of 10% Triton X-100 was added. The fraction was left on ice for 7 min with occasional mixing and then centrifuged at 11,000 × g at 4 °C for 5 min. The supernatant was loaded onto a 4-ml Q-Sepharose column pre-equilibrated in wash buffer (25 mm Hepes, pH 7.5, 10 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 1 mg/ml Pefabloc, 10 μg/ml Leupeptin) containing 20 mm KCl. The column was washed with 8 ml of the 20 mm KCl wash buffer followed by 8 ml of 100 mm KCl in wash buffer and then eluted with 200 mm KCl in wash buffer. One-ml fractions were collected, and 15 μl of each fraction were assayed for protein with a Coomassie dye reagent (Pierce); the editing activity had earlier been found to co-elute with the peak protein concentration within the 200 mm eluted fractions (20Oppegard L.M. Connell G.J. Int. J. Parasitol. 2002; 32: 859-866Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). The peak protein fractions were diluted 2-fold in wash buffer and then loaded onto a 3.5-ml SP-Sepharose column that had been pre-equilibrated in 100 mm KCl wash buffer. After washing for 8 ml, the column was eluted in 200 mm KCl wash buffer, 250-μl fractions were collected, and 15 μl from each was assayed for protein. The protein concentration of the pooled SP-eluted fractions was ∼0.02 μg/μl. All chromatography was performed at 4 °C. Prior to freezing at -80 °C, bovine serum albumin (Roche Applied Science) was added to a final concentration of 1 mg/ml to the SP fractions. RNAs—RNAs were transcribed in vitro from the corresponding single-stranded oligodeoxynucleotide templates as previously described (25Milligan J.F. Groebe D.R. Witherell G.W. Uhlenbeck O.C. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 8783-8798Crossref PubMed Scopus (1882) Google Scholar). The transcription reactions contained a 4 mm concentration of each rNTP, 5.5 mm GMP, 40 mm Tris (pH 8.2 at 22 °C), 22 mm MgCl2, 2 mm spermidine, 5 mm dithiothreitol, 0.01% Triton X-100, and 50 units of T7 RNA polymerase (Invitrogen) in a 100-μl volume. Transcriptions of radiolabeled RNAs also contained 20 μCi of [α-32P]UTP. The RNAs were gel-purified, eluted, and concentrated by ethanol precipitation. All RNAs used as substrates for the editing reaction were circularized with T4 RNA ligase to block a 3′ U addition activity that would otherwise complicate the assay. The ligation reactions were at 37 °C for 2 h and contained 50 mm Tris (pH 8.7 at 22 °C), 10 mm MgCl2, 10 mm dithiothreitol, 0.25 μg/μl bovine serum albumin, 1 mm rATP, 2.1 m Me2SO, 2.5 μm RNA, and 0.3 units/μl of T4 RNA ligase (New England Biolabs). After 2 h, the reactions were terminated by phenol/CHCl3 extraction and ethanol-precipitated. The RNAs were resuspended in 7 μl of distilled H2O, 3 μl of urea loading dye (10 m urea, 0.05% bromphenol blue, 0.05% xylene cyanole), and the circular product was resolved on a 60-cm-long/0.75-mm-thick 9% polyacrylamide (acrylamide/bisacrylamide weight ratio of 19:1)/8 m urea gel. The RNA bands were visualized by UV shadowing, excised, eluted, and ethanol-precipitated. Editing Assay—One pmol of the radiolabeled circular RNAs was heated at 65 °C for 3 min in a 10-μl volume containing 25 mm Tris (pH 8.1 at 27 °C) and 0.2 mm EDTA. After adding 25 μl of editing buffer (40 mm KCl, 20 mm MgCl2, 6 mm potassium phosphate, 40 mm dithiothreitol, 2 mm ATP, 2 mm GTP, 2 mm UTP, 1 mg/ml Pefabloc, 10 μg/ml leupeptin), the RNA was left at room temperature for 10 min, at which point 15 μl of the SP fractionated extract (∼0.3 μg of protein) were added, and the reactions left at 27 °C for 1 h. The reactions were terminated by the addition of EDTA to 20 mm, SDS to 0.5%, and proteinase K to 200 μg/ml. After heating 30 min at 37 °C, the reactions were phenol/CHCl3-extracted, and the RNA was ethanol-precipitated. The RNA was resuspended in 3 μl of distilled H2O and 1 μl of urea dye, and the products were resolved on a 60-cm-long/0.4-mm-thick 9% polyacrylamide, 8 m urea gel. The edited signal was quantified after PhosphorImaging scanning (Amersham Biosciences). Oppegard L.M. Connell G.J. RNA. 2003; 9: 469-483Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Diverse Editing Substrates—Selection-amplification (21Tuerk C. Gold L. Science. 1990; 249: 505-510Crossref PubMed Scopus (7890) Google Scholar, 22Ellington A.D. Szostak J.W. Nature. 1990; 346: 818-822Crossref PubMed Scopus (7470) Google Scholar) was initially exploited in order to identify the sequence and structural requirements for the A + U-dependent editing reaction. A random mixture of the four standard nucleotides was substituted at 23 positions of the A + U element (Fig. 1A). RNAs within the random population that had the sequence and structure able to support in vitro U additions independent of added gRNA were partitioned from the bulk unedited population on the basis of their slower mobility on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel. The RNAs were circularized with T4 RNA ligase prior to extract treatment so as to prevent a terminal uridylyltransferase activity, present within the editing extract, from adding Us to the 3′-end, which would have interfered with the selection. Edited RNA was excised from the gel and amplified by RT-PCR and T7 RNA polymerase-mediated transcription for additional cycles of enrichment. Low stringent primer annealing and extension conditions were chosen so that the editing sites within the flanking fixed sequence could be regenerated for subsequent selection. However, editing sites within the random region would not be regenerated by this strategy. In addition to selecting RNAs that are permutations of the A + U element, it was possible that cis-acting gRNAs would be obtained from the selection. In fact, 14 of the RNAs selected after four cycles of selection clearly function as cis-acting gRNAs that guide U insertions between nucleotides 16 and 21 of the fixed sequence (labeled Group A in Fig. 1B). The first six RNAs within group A were used to define the critical RNA sequence and structure required for efficient gRNA-directed editing and have been described (9Pai R.D. Oppegard L.M. Connell G.J. RNA. 2003; 9: 469-483Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). However, the majority of the selected RNAs did not appear to be related to the group A RNAs, and there also did not appear to be any obvious predicted structural similarity among these RNAs. Several selected sequences 8-14 nucleotides in length are each present within two different RNAs and were used to define the groups labeled B-F (Fig. 1B). Even within each group, however, it was difficult to fold the two RNAs into a structure that placed the consensus sequence within a similar conformation. The majority of the selected RNAs did not appear to be related either to the seven groups or to each other and were defined as group G. Since it was possible that RNAs were selected without meeting the intended criterion of being an editing substrate, two of the RNAs labeled B-1 and C-1 were chosen for further characterization. Treatment of both RNAs with editing extract resulted in a ladder of slower migrating products not detected with the starting random population (Fig. 1C). The slower migrating products are consistent with RNAs B-1 and C-1 being substrates for the in vitro U insertion reaction. However, unlike the parental A + U sequence, the predominant product formed with the editing of RNAs B-1 and C-1 is consistent with the insertion of only one U. Secondary Structure of RNAs B-1 and C-1—The location of the in vitro U insertions was determined for both RNAs B-1 and C-1. After treating the RNAs with extract, the edited product was resolved on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel, excised and reverse-transcribed in two parallel reactions using two nonoverlapping primers. The two different reverse transcription primers permitted U insertions to be detected throughout the entire sequence within each population of edited RNA. After the reverse transcriptions, a 3′ oligo(dA) extension was added to the cDNAs using terminal transferase and the product was PCR-amplified for cloning and sequencing. The major editing site for both RNAs B-1 and C-1 is located between nucleotides 59 and 62 (Fig. 2A). There is ambiguity in the precise localization because nucleotides 60 and 61 are Us, and it has been demonstrated for other RNAs that editing can occur both 5′ and 3′ of a genomically encoded U (9Pai R.D. Oppegard L.M. Connell G.J. RNA. 2003; 9: 469-483Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). In addition to the major editing site(s), both RNAs also had several minor editing sites. The multiple editing sites were of interest, because it is also a characteristic of the A + U element-dependent reaction (18Brown L.M. Burbach B.J. McKenzie B.A. Connell G.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6295-6304Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). In order to obtain insight into the relevant secondary structure of RNAs B-1 and C-1, conformations that placed a potential guiding nucleotide opposite the major site of in vitro editing were initially identified using an RNA folding algorithm (27Zuker M. Nucleic Acids Res. 2003; 31: 3406-3415Crossref PubMed Scopus (10151) Google Scholar). These were subsequently tested by altering the number of purines at positions that potentially could act as guiding nucleotides in order to determine whether the number of Us inserted during the editing reaction was altered in the predicted manner. Changing the number of purines from zero to two at position 21 had the predicted effect on the number of insertions within both RNAs (Fig. 2B). Sequencing confirmed that the change in the number of insertions was occurring between nucleotides 59 and 62 (not shown), the major editing site. The relatively low background of incorrect insertions, especially when there are no guiding nucleotides at position 21 (Fig. 2B, lanes 3 and 9), is also consistent with the other editing sites making only a minor contribution to the editing signal. Knowing the location of the guiding nucleotides and the major site of insertion provided constraints on the possible secondary structures. Most of the non-group A selected RNAs can be folded into hairpin loop structures similar to RNAs B-1 and C-1 (not shown); these include the group B-F RNAs and RNAs G-1 through G-30 (Fig. 1B). In order to refine the predicted secondary structures, both RNAs B-1 and C-1 were probed with the RNA-modifying agents DMS and CMCT (Fig. 2, C and D). Whereas DMS modifies As and Cs at Watson-Crick positions that are not involved in secondary or tertiary interactions, CMCT modifies Gs and Us at nonprotected Watson-Crick positions. Sites of modification were detected by RT-primer extension. The intensity from each RT product of the treated RNA was corrected for the corresponding modification-independent termination, and the ratio of the corrected intensity obtained under native conditions to that obtained under denaturing conditions was calculated for each position (Fig. 2A). Values could not be calculated at those positions where there are strong modification-independent RT terminations or limited reactivity under denaturing conditions. Most of the nucleotides within the predicted hairpin loop of RNA B-1 (nucleotides 33-50) are reactive under native conditions, and the nucleotides within the predicted helix formed by the pairing of (G-51, C-52, G-53, U-54, U-55, U-56) with (U-32, G-31, C-30, G-29, G-28, A-27) are mostly protected under the native reaction conditions (Fig. 2, A and C). Although the helix could potentially be extended further through the pairing of (A-57, A-58) with (U-26, U-25) and the pairing of (U-48, A-49, U-50) with (A-35, U-34, G-33), the modifications are more consistent with these nucleotides being unpaired. A-21 is more reactive than both A-22 and A-23, which is consistent with it being the unpaired guiding nucleotide. The modification reactions are also consistent with the helix predicted to form through the pairing of (G-62, U-63, U-64 C-65, U-66) with (U-20, A-19, G-18, G-17, G-16, G-15); however, modification-independent RT terminations limit the value of chemical probing within this region. The chemical probing is also mostly consistent with the proposed folding of RNA C-1 (Fig. 2, A and D). The ambiguity in the RNA C-1 secondary structure is primarily within the region predicted to form the internal G-G bulge (U-49, C-50, G-51, G-32, G-33, A-34). U-49 is not protected, and A-34, C-50, and C-52 are only partially protected, which is not completely consistent with the proposed structure but could result from fraying of base pairs near the end of the helix. Approximately 20% of the RNAs obtained from the fourth cycle of selection can also be folded with analogous G-G bulge loops, including RNAs B-2, D-1, E-1, E-2, and G-1 through G-11. The discrepancy between the in vitro selection of RNAs with the G-G bulge and chemical modification results may reflect an increased stability of the G-G bulged loop region in the presence of editing extract relative to the chemical probing when no protein is present.
